inlineContent.text: This class serves as a default material with a wide variety of rendering features and properties without the need to write shader code. See the tutorial below for details.

abstract.text: Abstract base class for defining the 3D rendering properties of meshes.
A 3D particle emitter.
Texture that controls the strength of the refraction per-pixel. Multiplied by
The strength of the refraction effect.

The number of layers to use for parallax occlusion mapping when the camera is up close to the material. Higher values result in a more convincing depth effect, especially in materials that have steep height changes. Higher values have a significant cost on the GPU, so it should only be increased on materials where it makes a significant visual difference.
How much to scale the
coordinates. This is multiplied by
in the vertex function. The Z component is used when
is enabled, but it is not used anywhere else.
Texture used to specify the normal at a given pixel. The
only uses the red and green channels; the blue and alpha channels are ignored. The normal read from
is oriented around the surface normal provided by the
If
, enables subsurface scattering transmittance. Only effective if
is
. See also
The depth of the subsurface scattering transmittance effect.
Filter flags for the texture. See
for options.
If
, forces a conversion of the
from sRGB color space to linear color space. See also
If
, the shader will keep the scale set for the mesh. Otherwise, the scale is lost when billboarding. Only applies when
is not .billboardDisabled.

Sets whether the shading takes place, per-pixel, per-vertex or unshaded. Per-vertex lighting is faster, making it the best choice for mobile applications, however it looks considerably worse than per-pixel. Unshaded rendering is the fastest, but disables all interactions with lights.
Texture that specifies how much surface emits light at a given point.
Adjusts the strength of specular reflections. Specular reflections are composed of scene reflections and the specular lobe which is the bright spot that is reflected from light sources. When set to
, no specular reflections will be visible. This differs from the .specularDisabled
as .specularDisabled only applies to the specular lobe from the light source.
Types that conform to VariantRepresentable can be stored directly in
with no conversion.  These include all of the Variant types from Godot (for
example
), Godot objects (those that subclass
SwiftGodot.Object) as well as the built-in Swift types UInt8, Int64 and Double.
Controls how the object faces the camera. See
If
, the proximity fade effect is enabled. The proximity fade effect fades out each pixel based on its distance to another object.
How much to offset the
coordinates. This amount will be added to
in the vertex function. This can be used to offset a texture. The Z component is used when
is enabled, but it is not used anywhere else.
The hashing scale for Alpha Hash. Recommended values between
and
Sets the strength of the rim lighting effect.
Enables multichannel signed distance field rendering shader. Use
and
to configure MSDF parameters.
A
that contains vertex array-based geometry.
Texture that defines the strength of the clearcoat effect and the glossiness of the clearcoat. Strength is specified in the red channel while glossiness is specified in the green channel.
If
, the backlight effect is enabled. See also
If
, normal mapping is enabled. This has a slight performance cost, especially on mobile GPUs.
If
, enables the vertex grow setting. This can be used to create mesh-based outlines using a second material pass and its
set to .cullFront. See also
Luminance of emitted light, measured in nits (candela per square meter). Only available when
is enabled. The default is roughly equivalent to an indoor lightbulb.
If
, rim effect is enabled. Rim lighting increases the brightness at glancing angles on an object.
Texture used to control the subsurface scattering strength. Stored in the red texture channel. Multiplied by
The Occlusion/Roughness/Metallic texture to use. This is a more efficient replacement of
and
in
. Ambient occlusion is stored in the red channel. Roughness map is stored in the green channel. Metallic map is stored in the blue channel. The alpha channel is ignored.
A lower number blends the texture more softly while a higher number blends the texture more sharply.
Grows object vertices in the direction of their normals. Only effective if
is
The number of vertical frames in the particle sprite sheet. Only enabled when using .billboardParticles. See
Texture used to control the roughness per-pixel. Multiplied by

The material’s transparency mode. Some transparency modes will disable shadow casting. Any transparency mode other than .disabled has a greater performance impact compared to opaque rendering. See also
If
, the object is rendered at the same size regardless of distance.
If
, flips the mesh’s binormal vectors when interpreting the height map. If the heightmap effect looks strange when the camera moves (even with a reasonable
), try setting this to
If
, enables the detail overlay. Detail is a second texture that gets mixed over the surface of the object based on
and
’s alpha channel. This can be used to add variation to objects, or to blend between two different albedo/normal textures.
Distance over which the fade effect takes place. The larger the distance the longer it takes for an object to fade.
The width of the shape outline.
Surface reflection. A value of
represents a perfect mirror while a value of
completely blurs the reflection. See also
If
, instead of using

textures will use a triplanar texture lookup to determine how to apply textures. Triplanar uses the orientation of the object’s surface to blend between texture coordinates. It reads from the source texture 3 times, once for each axis and then blends between the results based on how closely the pixel aligns with each axis. This is often used for natural features to get a realistic blend of materials. Because triplanar texturing requires many more texture reads per-pixel it is much slower than normal UV texturing. Additionally, because it is blending the texture between the three axes, it is unsuitable when you are trying to achieve crisp texturing.
Specifies how the
should blend with the current
. See
for options.
If
, particle animations are looped. Only enabled when using .billboardParticles. See
Sets how
interacts with
. Can either add or multiply. See
for options.
Determines which side of the triangle to cull depending on whether the triangle faces towards or away from the camera. See
If
, the vertex color is used as albedo color.

A high value makes the material appear more like a metal. Non-metals use their albedo as the diffuse color and add diffuse to the specular reflection. With non-metals, the reflection appears on top of the albedo color. Metals use their albedo as a multiplier to the specular reflection and set the diffuse color to black resulting in a tinted reflection. Materials work better when fully metal or fully non-metal, values between
and
should only be used for blending between metal and non-metal sections. To alter the amount of reflection use
Represents a straight ribbon-shaped
with variable width.
If
, the body emits light. Emitting light makes the object appear brighter. The object can also cast light on other objects if a
, SDFGI, or
is used and this object is used in baked lighting.
The strength of the normal map’s effect.
The strength of the subsurface scattering effect. The depth of the effect is also controlled by
, which is set globally.
If
, anisotropy is enabled. Anisotropy changes the shape of the specular blob and aligns it to tangent space. This is useful for brushed aluminium and hair reflections.
The material’s base color.
Specifies the channel of the

in which the metallic information is stored. This is useful when you store the information for multiple effects in a single texture. For example if you stored metallic in the red channel, roughness in the blue, and ambient occlusion in the green you could reduce the number of textures you use.
The color used by the backlight effect. Represents the light passing through an object.
If
, the object receives no ambient light.
Types that conform to VariantStorable can be stored in a Variant and can be extracted
back out of a Variant.
Texture that defines the amount of ambient occlusion for a given point on the object.
How much to offset the
coordinates. This amount will be added to
in the vertex function. This can be used to offset a texture. The Z component is used when
is enabled, but it is not used anywhere else.
If

, enables the “shadow to opacity” render mode where lighting modifies the alpha so shadowed areas are opaque and non-shadowed areas are transparent. Useful for overlaying shadows onto a camera feed in AR.
Real-time global illumination (GI) probe.
Texture used to specify how the detail textures get blended with the base textures.
can be used together with
’s alpha channel (if any).
If
, triplanar mapping for
is calculated in world space rather than object local space. See also
The algorithm used for diffuse light scattering. See
If
, interprets the height map texture as a depth map, with brighter values appearing to be “lower” in altitude compared to darker values.
Determines when depth rendering takes place. See
. See also

The number of layers to use for parallax occlusion mapping when the camera is far away from the material. Higher values result in a more convincing depth effect, especially in materials that have steep height changes. Higher values have a significant cost on the GPU, so it should only be increased on materials where it makes a significant visual difference.
The strength of the anisotropy effect. This is multiplied by
’s alpha channel if a texture is defined there and the texture contains an alpha channel.
The amount of to blend light and albedo color when rendering rim effect. If
the light color is used, while
means albedo color is used. An intermediate value generally works best.
Texture used to control the backlight effect per-pixel. Added to
The color to multiply the subsurface scattering transmittance effect with. Ignored if
is
Sets the roughness of the clearcoat pass. A higher value results in a rougher clearcoat while a lower value results in a smoother clearcoat.
If
, depth testing is disabled and the object will be drawn in render order.
Sets the strength of the clearcoat effect. Setting to
looks the same as disabling the clearcoat effect.
Texture used to specify metallic for an object. This is multiplied by
Distance at which the object appears fully opaque.
Texture to multiply by
. Used for basic texturing of objects.
The point size in pixels. See
Threshold at which the alpha scissor will discard values. Higher values will result in more pixels being discarded. If the material becomes too opaque at a distance, try increasing
. If the material disappears at a distance, try decreasing
A lower number blends the texture more softly while a higher number blends the texture more sharply.
If
, flips the mesh’s tangent vectors when interpreting the height map. If the heightmap effect looks strange when the camera moves (even with a reasonable
), try setting this to
A PBR (Physically Based Rendering) material to be used on 3D objects.
The width of the range around the shape between the minimum and maximum representable signed distance.
If
, subsurface scattering is enabled. Emulates light that penetrates an object’s surface, is scattered, and then emerges. Subsurface scattering quality is controlled by
If

, the object will not be affected by fog (neither volumetric nor depth fog). This is useful for unshaded or transparent materials (e.g. particles), which without this setting will be affected even if fully transparent.
Computes and stores baked lightmaps for fast global illumination.
Texture that specifies the per-pixel normal of the detail overlay. The
texture only uses the red and green channels; the blue and alpha channels are ignored. The normal read from
is oriented around the surface normal provided by the
Texture that specifies the color of the detail overlay.
’s alpha channel is used as a mask, even when the material is opaque. To use a dedicated texture as a mask, see
If
, use
coordinates to look up from the
The number of horizontal frames in the particle sprite sheet. Only enabled when using .billboardParticles. See
Virtual base class for applying visual properties to an object, such as color and roughness.
Abstract base class for defining the 3D rendering properties of meshes.
If
, height mapping is enabled (also called “parallax mapping” or “depth mapping”). See also
. Height mapping is a demanding feature on the GPU, so it should only be used on materials where it makes a significant visual difference.
The method for rendering the specular blob. See
If
, the object receives no shadow that would otherwise be cast onto it.
The heightmap scale to use for the parallax effect (see

). The default value is tuned so that the highest point (value = 255) appears to be 5 cm higher than the lowest point (value = 0). Higher values result in a deeper appearance, but may result in artifacts appearing when looking at the material from oblique angles, especially when the camera moves. Negative values can be used to invert the parallax effect, but this is different from inverting the texture using
as the material will also appear to be “closer” to the camera. In most cases,
should be kept to a positive value.
If
, triplanar mapping for
is calculated in world space rather than object local space. See also
Specifies whether to use
or
for the detail layer. See
for options.
Specifies the channel of the

in which the ambient occlusion information is stored. This is useful when you store the information for multiple effects in a single texture. For example if you stored metallic in the red channel, roughness in the blue, and ambient occlusion in the green you could reduce the number of textures you use.
The type of alpha antialiasing to apply. See
If
, ambient occlusion is enabled. Ambient occlusion darkens areas based on the
Distance at which the object starts to become visible. If the object is less than this distance away, it will be invisible.
The material’s blend mode.
Specifies the channel of the

in which the roughness information is stored. This is useful when you store the information for multiple effects in a single texture. For example if you stored metallic in the red channel, roughness in the blue, and ambient occlusion in the green you could reduce the number of textures you use.
The texture to use for multiplying the intensity of the subsurface scattering transmittance intensity. See also
. Ignored if
is

Texture that offsets the tangent map for anisotropy calculations and optionally controls the anisotropy effect (if an alpha channel is present). The flowmap texture is expected to be a derivative map, with the red channel representing distortion on the X axis and green channel representing distortion on the Y axis. Values below 0.5 will result in negative distortion, whereas values above 0.5 will result in positive distortion.
The emitted light’s color. See
Multiplier for emitted light. See
If
, render point size can be changed.
If
, enables parts of the shader required for
trails to function. This also requires using a mesh with appropriate skinning, such as
or
. Enabling this feature outside of materials used in
meshes will break material rendering.
If

, clearcoat rendering is enabled. Adds a secondary transparent pass to the lighting calculation resulting in an added specular blob. This makes materials appear as if they have a clear layer on them that can be either glossy or rough.
Specifies which type of fade to use. Can be any of the
s.
Use
to read from the
If
, uses parallax occlusion mapping to represent depth in the material instead of simple offset mapping (see
). This results in a more convincing depth effect, but is much more expensive on the GPU. Only enable this on materials where it makes a significant visual difference.
Framework to write Godot Game Extensions using the Swift Programming Language.
A PBR (Physically Based Rendering) material to be used on 3D objects. Uses an ORM texture.
Repeat flags for the texture. See
for options.
If
, instead of using

textures will use a triplanar texture lookup to determine how to apply textures. Triplanar uses the orientation of the object’s surface to blend between texture coordinates. It reads from the source texture 3 times, once for each axis and then blends between the results based on how closely the pixel aligns with each axis. This is often used for natural features to get a realistic blend of materials. Because triplanar texturing requires many more texture reads per-pixel it is much slower than normal UV texturing. Additionally, because it is blending the texture between the three axes, it is unsuitable when you are trying to achieve crisp texturing.
If
, subsurface scattering will use a special mode optimized for the color and density of human skin, such as boosting the intensity of the red channel in subsurface scattering.
How much to scale the
coordinates. This is multiplied by
in the vertex function. The Z component is used when
is enabled, but it is not used anywhere else.
Specifies the channel of the

in which the refraction information is stored. This is useful when you store the information for multiple effects in a single texture. For example if you stored refraction in the red channel, roughness in the blue, and ambient occlusion in the green you could reduce the number of textures you use.
Amount that ambient occlusion affects lighting from lights. If
, ambient occlusion only affects ambient light. If
, ambient occlusion affects lights just as much as it affects ambient light. This can be used to impact the strength of the ambient occlusion effect, but typically looks unrealistic.
The texture to use as a height map. See also
Threshold at which antialiasing will be applied on the alpha channel.
The intensity of the subsurface scattering transmittance effect.
Represents a straight tube-shaped
with variable width.
If
, vertex colors are considered to be stored in sRGB color space and are converted to linear color space during rendering. If
, vertex colors are considered to be stored in linear color space and are rendered as-is. See also
Texture used to set the strength of the rim lighting effect per-pixel. Multiplied by
If
, the refraction effect is enabled. Distorts transparency based on light from behind the object.
